abstract: Analysts say IBM is struggling to offset the erosion of some of its traditional hardware, software and services businesses.
lead_para: IBM on Monday reported sharply lower profits and sales in the third quarter, raising questions about the progress of its corporate transition to new businesses.
headline: IBM Sales and Profit Dropped 14% in Third Quarter

abstract: Tech earnings season is going into full swing, with companies including Yahoo, IBM, Google and Microsoft set to report quarterly results this week. Their financial data may offer insight into which companies are gaining the upper hand in some tech battles.
lead_para: The technology industry’s financial data is set to go on full display this week.
headline: Daily Report: Tech Tussles Take Center Stage in Earnings

abstract: Amazon Web Services is starting to offer capabilities that compete head-to-head with longtime business computing giants like Oracle and IBM.
lead_para: LAS VEGAS — There is a famous story from the early days of Google that goes something like this: When a group of New York media big shots heard about the huge efficiency of search advertising, which could hurt their own businesses, the memorable reaction of one of them was a more vulgar take on “You’re fussing with the magic!”
headline: Amazon Messes With Billions in Corporate Computing Dollars

abstract: The finding may be the key to once again increasing the speed of computer processors, which has been stalled for the last decade.
lead_para: In the semiconductor business, it is called the “red brick wall” — the limit of the industry’s ability to shrink transistors beyond a certain size.
headline: IBM Scientists Find New Way to Shrink Transistors

abstract: A growing number of companies like IBM, Cisco Systems and Microsoft have partnerships with Chinese companies with ties to the military, and experts are questioning those links.
lead_para: HONG KONG — One Chinese technology company receives crucial technical guidance from a former People’s Liberation Army rear admiral. Another company developed the electronics on China’s first atomic bomb. A third sells technology to China’s air-to-air missile research academy.
headline: U.S. Tech Giants May Blur National Security Boundaries in China Deals

abstract: Analysts say Twitter’s cuts show something may be wrong inside the company. But when tech giants cut thousands of jobs, the hand-wringing is far more subdued.
lead_para: In the scheme of things, 336 is not a terribly large number when it comes to corporate layoffs. That is, unless people have thought you were the Next Big Thing — or at least one of the next big things that probably won’t be quite as big as Facebook.
headline: Daily Report: Putting Twitter’s Layoffs in Perspective

abstract: Big Blue, which has just bought most of the assets of the Weather Company, continues to build out the capabilities of its showpiece “cognitive” computing service as it looks for new ways to make money.
lead_para: In drought-stricken San Francisco, when the forecast calls for rain, it is a reason for celebration. And when that forecast doesn’t pan it out, as happened on Wednesday, it is a reason to deride whoever made that forecast.
headline: Daily Report: IBM’s New Weatherman Is Named Watson

abstract: Pfizer and Allergan Consider Merger | Goldman to Pay $50 Million Over Fed Leak | Former Goldman Executive to Join TPG
lead_para: DEUTSCHE BANK TO CUT 35,000 JOBS UNDER NEW STRATEGY | Deutsche Bank said it would cut as many as 35,000 jobs over the next two years as part of a strategy to overhaul the German lender, Chad Bray reports in DealBook.
headline: Morning Agenda: Deutsche Bank to Cut 35,000 Jobs Under New Strategy

abstract: The company said it had entered into an agreement to acquire most of the assets of the Weather Company, and its data could be combined with IBM’s Watson.
lead_para: IBM hopes it has a new use for Watson, its artificial intelligence business.
headline: IBM to Acquire the Weather Company

abstract: The computing giant disclosed in a regulatory filing that accounting practices in three countries are under scrutiny.
lead_para: The IBM Corporation said in a filing Tuesday that the United States. Securities and Exchange Commission was investigating how it accounted for certain transactions in the United States, Britain and Ireland.
headline: IBM Discloses S.E.C. Investigation

abstract: The technology research firm IDC predicts the pace of digital transformation of business is going to accelerate and increasingly hit every industry.
lead_para: It is the time of year when the big technology research shops gaze into the near future to identify trends that will have the most impact on corporate America and the tech industry over the next few years.
headline: Digital Transformation Going Mainstream in 2016, IDC Predicts

abstract: The tech stalwart has been hiring designers by the hundreds, all part of an accelerated approach to product development that is a major departure from the past.
lead_para: Phil Gilbert is a tall man with a shaved head and wire-rimmed glasses. He typically wears cowboy boots and bluejeans to work — hardly unusual these days, except he’s an executive at IBM, a company that still has a button-down suit-and-tie reputation. And in case you don’t get the message from his wardrobe, there’s a huge black-and-white photograph hanging in his office of a young Bob Dylan, hunched over sheet music, making changes to songs in the “Highway 61 Revisited” album. It’s an image, Mr. Gilbert will tell you, that conveys both a rebel spirit and hard work.
headline: IBM’s Design-Centered Strategy to Set Free the Squares

abstract: A venerable technology company is adopting a strategy that moves it into disruptive systems.
lead_para: Few companies – especially tech companies – can trace their history back more than a century.
headline: IBM Looks to Its Next Century

abstract: Phil Gilbert, head of design at IBM, is trying to get the technology giant to embrace a new concept that could potentially help the company, which has seen two years of declining revenue, rethink its approach.
lead_para: IBM has been associated with many things over the years. But few people would ever connect Big Blue, as IBM is sometimes called, with a progressive attitude toward design.
headline: Daily Report: IBM Embraces Its Inner Designer

abstract: Dr. Amdahl played a crucial role in developing the IBM System/360 series, which influenced computer design for years.
lead_para: Gene Amdahl, a trailblazer in the design of IBM’s mainframe computers, which became the central nervous system for businesses large and small throughout the world, died on Tuesday at a nursing home in Palo Alto, Calif. He was 92.
headline: Gene Amdahl, Pioneer of Mainframe Computing, Dies at 92

abstract: Readers respond to “Setting Free the Squares” (Nov. 15).
lead_para: To the Editor:
headline: Computing by Design

abstract: From tabulating machines to artificial intelligence, IBM has been a leader in technology for the last century.
lead_para: From tabulating machines to artificial intelligence, IBM has been a leader in technology for the last century.
headline: IBM’s Century of Innovation

abstract: IBM and Yahoo are in the hot seat this week as both companies seek to rev up their growth. IBM, which reported results on Monday, posted falling sales. Next up is Yahoo.
lead_para: The number 14 played a big role in IBM’s earnings on Monday — and not in a good way.
headline: Daily Report: IBM and Yahoo in the Hot Seats

abstract: A closer look at recent partnerships that United States technology companies have formed with Chinese firms that have ties to the military.
lead_para: A closer look at recent partnerships that United States technology companies have formed with Chinese firms that have ties to the military.
headline: U.S. Tech Companies and Their Chinese Partners With Military Ties

abstract: Martin Schroeter, IBM’s chief financial officer, discusses the company’s latest earnings report.
lead_para: Martin Schroeter, IBM’s chief financial officer, discusses the company’s latest earnings report.
headline: IBM Lowers Its Earnings Forecast

abstract: A consortium of which the company is a part has made working versions of ultradense seven-nanometer chips, capable of holding much more information than existing chips.
lead_para: IBM said on Thursday that it had made working versions of ultradense computer chips, with roughly four times the capacity of today’s most powerful chips.
headline: IBM Discloses Working Version of a Much Higher-Capacity Chip

abstract: Facebook and other leading American technology companies see Africa as a place to experiment with new ways of expanding Internet access.
lead_para: Nearly two years ago, Facebook’s chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, announced an ambitious effort to connect the world’s poorest people to the Internet.
headline: Facebook and Other Tech Giants Expand Internet Access in Africa

abstract: The technology company, which does most of its business overseas, said most of the decline in the second quarter was because of the strong dollar.
lead_para: IBM is advancing rapidly into new fields like data analytics, cloud computing and mobile applications. And while the technology company’s second-quarter results showed encouraging progress in those businesses, it was not enough to translate into growth for the company as a whole, Steve Lohr reports.
headline: Daily Report: IBM Revenue Falls, Highlighting Challenges as It Shifts Course

abstract: The technology giant, which does most of its business overseas, said most of the decline in the second quarter was because of the strong dollar.
lead_para: IBM is advancing rapidly into new fields like data analytics, cloud computing and mobile applications. And while the technology company’s second-quarter results showed encouraging progress in those businesses, it was not enough to translate into growth for the company as a whole.
headline: IBM Revenue Falls 13% Despite Big Gains in New Fields

abstract: Google is becoming more public about its data centers, talking about its network and how much fiber it owns. The idea is to show off assets that Amazon, Microsoft and IBM cannot match in the competition for cloud customers.
lead_para: Google is wielding a new weapon against Amazon and Microsoft for cloud computing customers: itself.
headline: Google Is Its Own Secret Weapon in the Cloud

abstract: The deal will give Box, which already has a dedicated base of millions of users, access to IBM’s international reach and artificial-intelligence software.
lead_para: Corporate partnerships, like human ones, depend on what each side brings to the relationship and what each side needs.
headline: IBM and Box Team Up to Target Global Data-Storage Market

abstract: So-called software containers got backing from companies including Cisco Systems and Google, while another group of companies detailed plans to automate certain aspects of cloud computing.
lead_para: An unusual combination of big and small tech companies are working on ways to accelerate the development of cloud computing technologies.
headline: Tech Companies Line Up Behind ‘Containers’ and the Cloud

abstract: If you’re up on big data, you’ve heard of something called Hadoop. It may be worth billions, but some of Hadoop’s biggest backers look like they are moving on from it.
lead_para: There is increasing evidence that Hadoop — one of the most important technologies of the past several years for big data analysis —is not keeping up with the world that created it.
headline: Companies Move On From Big Data Technology Hadoop

abstract: IBM plans to invest heavily in accelerating the adoption of the open-source big data software, Spark. With the move, IBM is investing as much in its own future as in the open-source project.
lead_para: The IBM “endorsement effect” has often shaped the computer industry over the years. In 1981, when IBM entered the personal computer business, the company decisively pushed an upstart technology into the mainstream.
headline: IBM Invests to Help Open-Source Big Data Software — and Itself

abstract: IBM’s new mainframe is designed for challenges of the smartphone economy. The new machine’s success is critical to IBM.
lead_para: They seem a computing odd couple: the mainframe, the old workhorse, and the smartphone, the cool-kid computer of today.
headline: IBM Introduces z13, a Mainframe for the Smartphone Economy

abstract: New businesses are showing encouraging growth, but they are not yet large or profitable enough to offset challenges in the company’s traditional strengths.
lead_para: IBM is in the midst of a challenging transition, and its fourth-quarter financial results reflected that reality.
headline: IBM Revenue Slides as Revamping Takes Hold

abstract: A federal judge’s ruling on Thursday reflects the fallout from an appeals court decision in December that narrowed the definition of what constitutes insider trading.
lead_para: The fallout from a federal appellate ruling in December that narrowed the definition of what constitutes insider trading continues to affect other cases.
headline: Judge Vacates Guilty Pleas of Men Charged With Insider Trading in I.B.M. Stock

abstract: China will release its fourth-quarter growth on Monday night, and on Thursday the European Central Bank is expected to start its bond-buying program; IBM and General Electric will report results.
lead_para: CHINA WILL RELEASE FIGURES ON FOURTH-QUARTER GROWTH
headline: Economic Data From China, and Stimulus From the E.C.B.

abstract: Investors have reason to be dissatisfied. The trouble is that IBM has already exhausted the typical activist playbook.
lead_para: Requests from some big shareholders for activism at IBM are likely to go nowhere. There’s no question that the company’s investors have reason to be dissatisfied. Big Blue’s top line has shrunk for 11 consecutive quarters, shares have fallen about 25 percent from their high, and there’s no hint that the company has discovered a way to reverse course. The snag is that activists don’t have an obvious playbook for IBM’s recovery either.
headline: Call for Activism at IBM Is Likely to Go Unheard

abstract: Revenue fell 12 percent, to $19.6 billion in the latest quarter. The company says it will pursues new sources of growth, as some of its traditional hardware, software and services businesses erode.
lead_para: IBM reported earnings that surpassed Wall Street estimates, helped by solid sales of its new mainframe computers, even as its revenue fell, writes Steve Lohr.
headline: Daily Report: IBM Profit Slips as Company Enters Transition Year

abstract: Like IBM in the 1980s, the stock market giant has room to grow, but there are early signs of the end of its dominance.
lead_para: Apple can’t grow like this forever. No company can.
headline: Apple Won’t Always Rule. Just Look at IBM.

abstract: He and three colleagues formed a company that developed an off-the-shelf software package to integrate all of a company’s business operations.
lead_para: Klaus E. Tschira, whose pioneering role in the business software revolution made him one of Germany’s richest men, died on Tuesday in Heidelberg. He was 74.
headline: Klaus Tschira, Business Software Trailblazer, Dies at 74

abstract: IBM’s partnership with Teamsun, a Beijing company, to provide key technologies is similar to ones it has made elsewhere, but it has collided with political and trade issues.
lead_para: HONG KONG — Shen Changxiang, who once supervised the cybersecurity of China’s strategic missile arsenal and spearheaded computer security research for the navy, has warned of the perils of his country’s reliance on American technology.
headline: IBM Venture With China Stirs Concerns

abstract: The business unit will partner with companies including Apple, Medtronic and Johnson & Johnson, offering IBM’s Watson technology as a cloud-based tool at many levels of the health care industry.
lead_para: IBM is taking its Watson artificial-intelligence technology into health care in a big way with industry partners, a pair of acquisitions and an ambitious agenda.
headline: IBM Creates Watson Health to Analyze Medical Data

abstract: Data science offers a lot of promise in many fields, but for now, it seems wise to keep human beings in the loop.
lead_para: Armies of the finest minds in computer science have dedicated themselves to improving the odds of making a sale. The Internet-era abundance of data and clever software has opened the door to tailored marketing, targeted advertising and personalized product recommendations.
headline: If Algorithms Know All, How Much Should Humans Help?

abstract: Salesforce Said to be Preparing for Takeover Offers | Goldman Sachs Backs Bitcoin Company | Programmer’s Trial Resumes After 2 Jurors Removed | Secret Shutting Down
lead_para: SALESFORCE SAID TO BE PREPARING FOR TAKEOVER OFFERS  | Who wants to buy Salesforce.com? That was the big question Wednesday following a report by Bloomberg News that the cloud software giant had hired financial advisers to field takeover inquiries after it was approached by a potential buyer. Unidentified people with knowledge of the matter told Bloomberg News that it was not certain that any deal would be struck, and they didn’t name any possible buyers.
headline: Morning Agenda: Salesforce Said to be Preparing for Takeover Offers

abstract: In what the company has said will be a transition year, its revenue fell 12 percent, to $19.6 billion, but operating profits rose.
lead_para: IBM reported earnings on Monday that surpassed Wall Street’s estimates, helped by solid sales of its new mainframe computers, even as its revenue fell.
headline: IBM First-Quarter Earnings Top Wall St. Expectations

abstract: IBM and Facebook are forming a marketing partnership. It combines their data skills to help retailers and consumer brands move toward personalized marketing.
lead_para: Personalized marketing — the product pitch or message that really hits its target, the right person at the right time — is the much-discussed ideal in advertising and sales.
headline: IBM and Facebook in Marketing Partnership

abstract: Apple, IBM and Japan Post are partnering to provide a technology service for older adults. The venture reflects the larger ambitions of each company.
lead_para: Japan is an incubator of aging. More than other countries, it is a graying nation. Twenty-five percent of its population, or 33 million people, is age 65 or older, more than double the global average.
headline: Apple, IBM and Japan Post See Profit in the Old-Age Market

abstract: Ms. Ruderman, a vice president and chief financial officer for IBM Latin America, keeps an open mind and an open office.
lead_para: A changing landscape
headline: Natalia Maria Ruderman of IBM: A Sweet Spot for Global Traditions

abstract: The chip maker NXP and Hewlett Packard need strong demand to compensate for falling prices. The trouble is, that has not happened, says the author.
lead_para: A $15 billion technology M.&A. spree is a poor fix for limp sales.
headline: Tech Deals That Are Poor Fixes for Limp Sales

abstract: IBM adds another big data source to its data analysis business in a partnership with the Weather Company.
lead_para: Data partnerships are a key ingredient in IBM’s long-term strategy, and the company is announcing a big one on Tuesday with the Weather Company.
headline: IBM Scores Weather Data Deal and Starts Internet of Things Unit

abstract: IBM and Twitter rolled out their data services for business. They are the first products of a venture that is strategically important to both companies.
lead_para: When IBM announced its partnership with Twitter last October, the move seemed both promising and logical.
headline: IBM Introduces Twitter-Fueled Data Services for Business

abstract: A number of big tech companies with an interest in building out the big data market have announced a standard for core elements of a technology framework for data analysis.
lead_para: A key element of the big data business is getting what much of computer technology secretly craves: Normality.
headline: IBM, G.E. and Others Create Big Data Alliance

abstract: IBM is going deeper in the plan of its chief, Virginia Rometty, to rebuild the computing giant as a cloud company. At a giant show in Las Vegas, the company announced new kinds of security and services for cloud applications, along with data centers in new countries.
lead_para: IBM hopes everything looks better in IBM blue.
headline: IBM Tries to Paint the Computing Cloud Blue

abstract: IBM is making the case that its transition to higher-profit growth businesses is on pace. But analysts question whether they can grow faster than its traditional products decline.
lead_para: IBM’s top executives are holding their annual meeting with Wall Street analysts on Thursday, and it’s a skeptical crowd.
headline: IBM’s Leaders: 2015 Is a Transition Year, by Design

abstract: IBM is licensing its Watson technology, along with other cognitive computing capabilities, to SoftBank Telecom of Japan. Possible uses include smarter robots and more interactive phone services.
lead_para: IBM and SoftBank Telecom have agreed to bring the technology behind Watson — the IBM computer that won the television game show “Jeopardy!” — into Japan.
headline: IBM’s Watson Turns Japanese and Moves Into Robots

abstract: A survey by researchers at Harvard Business School shows a recognition among executives of social problems, but pessimism that they can be addressed.
lead_para: There is something appealing about the concept of “shared value.”
headline: Corporate Efforts to Address Social Problems Have Limits

abstract: The rise of modern computing owes much to human-centered software design. A leading computer scientist has built a web site highlighting the work of the field’s pioneers.
lead_para: The march of progress in computing is a climb. Each big step forward is also a step up, so that communication is further away from the machine, more on human terms.
headline: Humanizing Technology: A History of Human-Computer Interaction

abstract: IBM will announce Watson’s new abilities, but it hopes to open the system up to software developers, highlighting start-ups.
lead_para: IBM’s Watson is moving West and widening its ambitions.
headline: IBM’s A.I. System Watson to Get Second Home, on West Coast

abstract: The company is investing not only money but also some of its corporate reputation on the belief that it can be a technological leader in improving health care.
lead_para: IBM is adding medical images to the health data its Watson artificial-intelligence can mine to help doctors make diagnoses.
headline: IBM Adds Medical Images to Watson, Buying Merge Healthcare for $1 Billion

abstract: The Never-Ending Lawsuit | Why Disclosing C.E.O. Pay Might Bring Change | Apollo’s Stake in American Realty
lead_para: ACKMAN’S BET ON MONDELEZ SALES | By building up a $5.5 billion stake in Mondelez International, William A. Ackman is wagering that Mondelez could be persuaded to sell itself, Michael J. de la Merced and Alexandra Stevenson write in DealBook. The investment that Mr. Ackman’s Pershing Square Capital Management has made also highlights the widespread belief that the food sector is ripe for consolidation.
headline: Morning Agenda: Ackman’s Bet on Mondelez Sales

abstract: The Promontory Group has become a safe haven for former financial regulators looking to jump-start their post-Washington career.
lead_para: What do you do if you are IBM, supposedly one of the most reliable of blue-chip companies, and you want to acquire another company that is, shall we say, a little more ethically and morally challenged? You convince everyone that the new acquisition will allow IBM to advance the practical applications of the supercomputer named Watson, its mysterious and envelope-pushing entry into the exploding world of artificial intelligence.
headline: IBM Is Buying Consulting Firm for Its Washington Connections

abstract: The years of investment in its artificial intelligence effort, IBM executives say, are increasingly turning into moneymaking opportunities in sizable markets like health care and manufacturing.
lead_para: Watson, can you grow into a multibillion-dollar business and become the engine of IBM’s resurgence?
headline: IBM Is Counting on Its Bet on Watson, and Paying Big Money for It

abstract: In 1964, he transformed computing with the System/360, the foundation for the modern operating system that would host various software programs.
lead_para: Erich Bloch, who helped develop the IBM mainframe computer that, more than any other machine, propelled the world into the digital age, and who then shepherded the internet into broader use as director of the National Science Foundation, died on Nov. 25 in Washington. He was 91.
headline: Erich Bloch, Who Helped Develop IBM Mainframe, Dies at 91

abstract: World’s Biggest Hedge Fund Is Said to Slow Hiring | When Yahoo Ruled the Valley | A Bank Too Big to Jail
lead_para: SOFTBANK TO BUY LEADING CHIP DESIGNER Softbank has agreed to buy ARM Holdings, the British chip designer, for $32 billion, Leslie Picker and Mark Scott report in DealBook.
headline: Morning Agenda: SoftBank to Buy Leading Chip Designer

abstract: The transition from older, shrinking markets to new areas is proving difficult for tech’s most venerable companies. But that does not mean they won’t be able to reinvent themselves.
lead_para: For the tech industry’s venerable giants, the new stuff just doesn’t seem to be worth as much as the old stuff.
headline: Daily Report: IBM Caught Between the Old and the New

abstract: Markets Calmer After a Tumultuous Start to the Year | G.M. Invests in Lyft | Dalian Wanda to Buy Stake in Legendary Entertainment
lead_para: A GROWING CONFLICT IN WALL ST. BUYOUTS | A new, insidious relationship has developed among private equity firms, the banks that lend them billions to fund their buyouts and the law firms that advise on these deals,Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.
headline: Morning Agenda:  A Growing Conflict in Wall St. Buyouts

abstract: The overturning of a previous conviction in an insider trading case will test the S.E.C.’s efforts in two similar cases.
lead_para: The government files insider trading charges with much fanfare, declaring that the traders will be brought to justice and investors protected. But it is often years before the cases ever reach a courtroom, and a change in the law in December 2014 is making it more difficult for the Securities and Exchange Commission to prove violations in two cases that will start in the new year.
headline: In Cohen and I.B.M. Insider Trading Cases, Challenges for the S.E.C.

abstract: The computing giant’s new areas, such as data analytics, its Watson software and cloud computing, have yet to grow fast enough to supplant company’s eroding legacy products.
lead_para: IBM delivered fresh evidence on Tuesday of the financial challenge it faces in navigating a difficult transition to new technology businesses. Yet the company’s leaders insisted its performance also showed that its strategy was succeeding.
headline: IBM Reports Declines in Fourth-Quarter Profit and Revenue Despite Gains in New Fields

abstract: Mr. Sapper was especially revered by coffee connoisseurs for his lustrous stovetop Coban 9090 espresso maker, sold by Alessi, the Italian housewares manufacturer.
lead_para: Richard Sapper, an industrial designer whose sleek, precision-engineered prototypes spawned the Alessi espresso maker, the Tizio lamp and the IBM ThinkPad, died on Dec. 31 in Milan. He was 83.
headline: Richard Sapper, Designer of Sleek Housewares, Dies at 83

abstract: A deeper reading of recent earnings reports shows an industry in transition, and perhaps getting ready to get even bigger.
lead_para: Judging from the way the technology industry hypes itself, tech has a bright future, and always will. This week is a different matter.
headline: The No-Good Week in Tech’s (Hopeful) Trip to a Bright Future

abstract: The tentative Uber settlement leaves unresolved the dispute over the company’s practice of keeping its drivers as contractors instead of employees.
lead_para: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the week’s news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: Farhad and Mike’s Week in Tech: To Be or Not To Be an Uber Employee

abstract: The company reported a 21 percent decline in first-quarter earnings for the first quarter, though operating earnings per share were above estimates.
lead_para: IBM delivered a quarterly performance that shows the steady headway it is making in new businesses led by cloud computing and data-analysis software, like its Watson artificial intelligence technology.
headline: IBM Results Show Progress in Cloud and Data Analysis

abstract: When a value investor buys in, it’s a sign that a high-flying growth company has joined the ranks of venerable tech companies like IBM and Intel.
lead_para: With this week’s imprimatur from the legendary investor Warren Buffett, it should now be official: Apple, the world’s largest company by market capitalization and a symbol of American technological innovation, is a “value” stock.
headline: Warren Buffett Stake Suggests Apple Is All Grown Up

abstract: The tech giant will offer online tutorials, visual simulations and a gamelike system that will parcel out access to a modest quantum computer.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Prime Minister Justin Trudeau of Canada grabbed international headlines recently with a simple explanation of a cutting-edge technology called quantum computing. Now IBM is trying to do something similar by making a research-oriented quantum computer and a — relatively — simple tutorial available online for anyone to try.
headline: IBM Wants Everyone to Try a Quantum Computer

abstract: The executives meeting with Mr. Trump in Manhattan on Wednesday include Elon Musk of Tesla, Timothy D. Cook of Apple and Jeff Bezos of Amazon.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — At the top of the agenda when President-elect Donald J. Trump meets with tech leaders on Wednesday afternoon: jobs, jobs and more jobs.
headline: When Trump Meets Tech Leaders, Jobs Will Be on the Agenda

abstract: Yahoo and the Buyback Mirage | Law Graduate Who Sued Her School Loses at Trial
lead_para: ETHEREUM CHALLENGES BITCOIN | A new virtual gold rush is under way. Ethereum, a rival to Bitcoin, has soared in value and climbed 1,000 percent over the last three months,Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook. Ethereum’s rise has attracted attention from giants like JPMorgan Chase, Microsoft and IBM.
headline: Morning Agenda: Ethereum Challenges Bitcoin

abstract: Amazon, Google, IBM and Microsoft are using high salaries and games pitting humans against computers to try to claim the standard on which all companies will build their A.I. technology.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — The resounding win by a Google artificial intelligence program over a champion in the complex board game Go this month was a statement — not so much to professional game players as to Google’s competitors.
headline: The Race Is On to Control Artificial Intelligence, and Tech’s Future

abstract: Argentina Reaches Deal With Hedge Funds | Britain’s Donald Trump Moment
lead_para: BARCLAYS TO SELL UNIT IN AFRICA | Barclays plans to sell down its stake in its African business, which was one of four pillars of Barclays’ strategy until last year, when Antony Jenkins was ousted from his job as chief executive,Chad Bray reports in DealBook.
headline: Morning Agenda: Barclays to Sell Unit in Africa

abstract: No Winners in Argentine Debt Fight | Safeguards for $6.9 Billion ADT Deal | Start-Ups Banking on Marijuana
lead_para: FED’S NEEL KASHKARI SAYS BANKS STILL TOO BIG TO FAIL | Neel Kashkari, the new president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, worked tirelessly to save the nation’s banks during the 2008 financial crisis. But now he thinks it is time to consider breaking them up,
headline: Morning Agenda: Fed’s Neel Kashkari Says Banks Still Too Big to Fail

abstract: This week we celebrate the victory of Google’s computer AI with a simple strategy challenge.
lead_para: Tremendous news last week: Google announced that it had created a computer program that defeated a professional player at Go – an event that many thought was still a decade away.
headline: Google Artificial Intelligence Beats Expert at Go Game

abstract: Creating a computer “personality” is as much an art as it is a science, and it’s a challenge that more and more software designers are grappling with.
lead_para: When computers speak, how human should they sound?
headline: Creating a Computer Voice That People Like

abstract: IBM has bought four companies since it created Watson Health last April, gaining data on millions of patients that it will use to try to improve care.
lead_para: IBM is looking to enhance the growth of its Watson Health business with the $2.6 billion purchase of Truven Health Analytics, which has data on the cost and treatment of more than 200 million patients.
headline: IBM Buys Truven for $2.6 Billion, Adding to Trove of Patient Data

abstract: Five years after a computer won “Jeopardy,” excitement over A.I. is at a peak, but the commercial potential of the achievement will take some years to be realized.
lead_para: When IBM’s Watson computer triumphed over human champions in the quiz show “Jeopardy!” it was a stunning achievement that suggested limitless horizons for artificial intelligence.
headline: The Promise of Artificial Intelligence Unfolds in Small Steps

abstract: Citigroup Chief Gets 27% Pay Raise | Dewey Case Leaves Troubling Questions
lead_para: KENNETH GRIFFIN JOINS TOP RANK OF ART PATRONS | Step aside, Steven A. Cohen, there’s another hedge fund manager with a voracious appetite for historic, and expensive, art.
headline: Morning Agenda: Kenneth Griffin Joins Top Rank of Art Patrons

abstract: IBM said that Promontory, which advises banks on regulatory matters, would mesh with its own offerings, including its Watson artificial intelligence platform.
lead_para: In recent years, IBM has been known for its forays into artificial intelligence and cloud computing. Now, the technology provider is moving deeper into financial consulting with the acquisition of a prominent — and at times controversial — Washington firm.
headline: IBM to Acquire Promontory, a Financial Consulting Firm

abstract: Four people involved in the creation of an industry partnership say its intent will be clear: to ensure that A.I. research is focused on things that will benefit people, not hurt them.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — For years, science-fiction moviemakers have been making us fear the bad things that artificially intelligent machines might do to their human creators. But for the next decade or two, our biggest concern is more likely to be that robots will take away our jobs or bump into us on the highway.
headline: How Tech Giants Are Devising Real Ethics for Artificial Intelligence

abstract: As G.E., Oracle, Salesforce.com and others push their A.I. products, it remains unclear whether potential customers understand how they will profit.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — This is the year artificial intelligence came into its own for mainstream businesses, at least as a marketing feature.
headline: Artificial Intelligence Software Is Booming. But Why Now?

abstract: The Partnership on AI unites Amazon, Facebook, Google, IBM and Microsoft to ease public fears of machines that are learning to think for themselves.
lead_para: Five major technology companies said Wednesday that they had created an organization to set the ground rules for protecting humans — and their jobs — in the face of rapid advances in artificial intelligence.
headline: Protecting Humans and Jobs From Robots Is 5 Tech Giants’ Goal

abstract: Watson, the IBM computer platform that dominated on “Jeopardy!” and has helped fight cancer, is part of a pilot program that will help teachers build personalized lesson plans.
lead_para: It knew enough about medical diagnoses and literature to beat “Jeopardy!” champions at their game, and has been put to use in cancer wards. Now, an IBM computer platform called Watson is taking on something really tough: teaching third-grade math.
headline: Next Target for IBM’s Watson? Third-Grade Math

abstract: A doctor who studies the history of presidents’ ailments calls for more transparency from the candidates.
lead_para: Donald Trump has begun questioning Hillary Clinton’s health, arguing recently that she lacks the “strength and stamina” to lead. When it comes to his own health, however, Mr. Trump has released only a bizarre letter from his doctor Harold Bornstein, which contains little medical detail. Mrs. Clinton has released a more detailed letter. In an interview, Dr. Robert Lahita, a professor of medicine at Rutgers University who has studied the history of presidential ailments, spoke about past presidents’ efforts to keep their illnesses under wraps and the need for more transparency.
headline: Are Trump and Clinton Healthy?

abstract: In a deal similar to the one that turned the tide against AIDS, manufacturers and charities will make chemotherapy drugs available in six poor countries at steep discounts.
lead_para: NAIROBI, Kenya — In a remarkable initiative modeled on the campaign against AIDS in Africa, two major pharmaceutical companies, working with the American Cancer Society, will steeply discount the prices of cancer medicines in Africa.
headline: As Cancer Tears Through Africa, Drug Makers Draw Up a Battle Plan

abstract: In certain fields, it’s like an arms race for companies to provide the best parental leave benefits for fathers as well as mothers.
lead_para: For 16 weeks during the spring and summer, Jim McMillan savored the joy of being a full-time father to his new baby, as well as to his 4-year-old son. A senior manager in the financial services audit practice at Ernst & Young’s New Orleans office, he was among the first group of fathers to get nearly four months of fully paid paternity leave.
headline: Millennials See Paternity Leave as a Priority

abstract: IBM researchers used an exotic material known as a Weyl semimetal to confirm the existence of a gravitational anomaly predicted in equations that describe the universe.
lead_para: The equations that describe the universe at the smallest and largest scales — how the tiniest elementary particles dance, how the space-time of the cosmos bends — predicted a slight incongruity, a tiny unbalancing in the numbers of certain particles under certain circumstances.
headline: An Experiment in Zurich Brings Us Nearer to a Black Hole’s Mysteries

abstract: Wimbledon’s commitment to its “tennis in an English garden” atmosphere means its technology and commercial partnerships must be very understated.
lead_para: WIMBLEDON, England — As the world’s oldest and most prestigious tennis tournament grows, a degree of quaintness remains essential.
headline: Wimbledon in Style for Marketers, Bringing a Reverent Hush to Their Ads

abstract: As some American companies pull back from hiring programmers a world away, new tech jobs are cropping up across the country.
lead_para: For years, American companies have been saving money by “offshoring” jobs — hiring people in India and other distant cubicle farms.
headline: Hot Spot for Tech Outsourcing: The United States

abstract: Programs promoting a skills-based labor market are gaining momentum and changing the way people are hired and trained for tech and other jobs.
lead_para: ROCKET CENTER, W.Va. — A few years ago, Sean Bridges lived with his mother, Linda, in Wiley Ford, W.Va. Their only income was her monthly Social Security disability check. He applied for work at Walmart and Burger King, but they were not hiring.
headline: A New Kind of Tech Job Emphasizes Skills, Not a College Degree

abstract: The Depository Trust and Clearing Corporation said it would begin using a financial ledger similar to the blockchain used by the virtual currency.
lead_para: After months of talk and hype, the world’s biggest banks have taken the first steps toward moving a significant piece of financial infrastructure onto a so-called blockchain — the technology introduced to the world by the virtual currency Bitcoin.
headline: Wall Street Clearinghouse to Adopt Bitcoin Technology

abstract: For decades, dominance in the technology industry was based on software or hardware. Now it is increasingly based on who owns the best data.
lead_para: Wealth and influence in the technology business have always been about gaining the upper hand in software or the machines that software ran on.
headline: Data Could Be the Next Tech Hot Button for Regulators

abstract: Why do federal regulators allow employers to expose workers to levels of toxic chemicals far higher than those considered safe for everyone?
lead_para: Last month, President Trump’s nomination of R. Alexander Acosta to be secretary of labor was approved by a Senate committee, even though the nominee’s testimony had left unclear whether he would be more interested in protecting employers’ prerogatives than in guarding workers’ interests.
headline: America’s Toxic Workplace Rules

abstract: Quarterly earnings reports from IBM, Qualcomm and Yahoo; a new Samsung smartphone; and a Facebook developer conference are on the horizon.
lead_para: It’s shaping up to be a busy week in tech.
headline: Tech Roundup: A Busy Week to Come

abstract: When seen in the light of pure machine learning (think IBM’s Watson), his behavior actually makes sense.
lead_para: It is hard to imagine a more scathing indictment of our ability to read another’s thoughts and intentions than our inability to predict Donald Trump’s next move. From the gross pre-election misjudgments to postelection bafflement, the best pundits are at a loss to accurately anticipate his response to matters like North Korean military aggressiveness or his moment-by-moment political gyrations and opinion reversals. Labeling Trump a narcissist, psychopath, megalomaniac or attention-impaired, or all of the above, might feel explanatory, but even when armed with the best psychoanalytic insights, we have no idea what he will do when presented with a new or unforeseen circumstance.
headline: Donald Trump, Our A.I. President

abstract: Walmart is testing real-world uses for the arcane technology behind the cryptocurrency Bitcoin, but significant challenges remain.
lead_para: Frank Yiannas has spent years looking in vain for a better way to track lettuce, steaks and snack cakes from farm and factory to the shelves of Walmart, where he is the vice president for food safety. When the company dealt with salmonella outbreaks, it often took weeks to trace where the bad ingredients came from.
headline: Blockchain: A Better Way to Track Pork Chops, Bonds, Bad Peanut Butter?

abstract: Prompted by President Trump’s immigration order and in some cases their employer’s own past, workers seek to set limits on cooperation with the administration.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — As soon as President Trump signed his executive order on immigration, some of the biggest tech companies went quiet. Their executives did not sign legal briefs, brandish statements or dissent on Twitter. They strove for business as usual.
headline: Activism Hits Even the Less Flashy Tech Companies

abstract: An alliance of about 30 companies, including Microsoft and JPMorgan Chase, has plans to standardize data gathering and tracking with software that is seen as harder to hack.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft, JPMorgan Chase and other corporate giants are joining forces to create a new kind of computing system based on the virtual currency network Ethereum.
headline: Business Giants to Announce Creation of a Computing System Based on Ethereum

abstract: A researcher for IBM analyzes interactions among medical professionals and cancer patients.
lead_para: Hannah Graffeo, 26, is a design researcher at IBM in New York.
headline: An Ethnographer of Cancer Care for IBM Watson

abstract: A partnership with H&R Block shows IBM’s strategy for artificial intelligence: Watson will be a smart assistant tailored for specific industries.
lead_para: In its first steps toward commercialization, IBM’s Watson took on grand, science-laden challenges like helping doctors diagnose cancer. But that is changing as IBM strives to build its artificial intelligence technology into a multibillion-dollar business.
headline: IBM Gives Watson a New Challenge: Your Tax Return

abstract: IBM has shifted its center of gravity halfway around the world to India, making it a high-tech example of the globalization trends that the Trump administration has railed against.
lead_para: BANGALORE, India — IBM dominated the early decades of computing with inventions like the mainframe and the floppy disk. Its offices and factories, stretching from upstate New York to Silicon Valley, were hubs of American innovation long before Microsoft or Google came along.
headline: IBM Now Has More Employees in India Than in the U.S.

abstract: Highlights posted on the U.S. Open’s website and app are selected by Watson, the IBM computer, using visual and audio information from matches.
lead_para: How exciting was it when Roger Federer, two points away from winning his third-round match at the United States Open last week, whipped a forehand crosscourt and out of reach of his luckless opponent, Feliciano López of Spain?
headline: Enjoy Those U.S. Open Highlights. A Computer Picked Them for You.

abstract: With just days left in a special legislative session, supporters of transgender restrictions are pessimistic about the chances of legislation in the face of business opposition.
lead_para: AUSTIN, Tex. — With little more than a week left in Texas’ 30-day special legislative session, a barrage of corporate advertising and activism has the potential to sink  legislation restricting transgender bathroom use that has been a flash point in the state’s culture wars.
headline: Texas Transgender Bathroom Bill Falters Amid Mounting Opposition

abstract: The deal is a big move to bring more software developers under IBM’s wing and hints at a bigger push into cloud computing.
lead_para: IBM is making a big move to bring more software developers under its wing by acquiring Red Hat, the largest distributor of the popular open-source operating system Linux, for $34 billion.
headline: IBM to Buy Red Hat, the Top Linux Distributor, for $34 Billion

abstract: The company has created a mobile version of its cyber training range to go on the road to businesses and communities that need to develop skills, fast.
lead_para: Two years ago, IBM opened one of the nation’s first commercial cybersecurity ranges in Cambridge, Mass., to let companies practice responding to simulated cyberattacks. It describes the experience as “a game of Clue mixed with a Disney roller-coaster ride.”
headline: IBM Takes Cybersecurity Training on the Road

abstract: When we think about investing, we want to make money, of course. But our personal values can also guide our investment choices. Take the Quiz.
headline: Are You Investing In What Matters To You? Take the Quiz.

abstract: Fueled by cheap credit, American corporations have been gorging on acquisitions. The party may soon be over.
lead_para: Corporations, like people, are pretty simple: They do what they are rewarded to do. So when the Federal Reserve, by keeping interest rates very low for nearly a decade, rewards companies for borrowing money by making it historically inexpensive to do so, it can’t be a surprise to anyone that that’s exactly what they did.
headline: When Blue Chip Companies Pile on Debt, It’s Time to Worry

abstract: Companies in a variety of fields, such as health care, government, food and supply chains, have begun exploring the technology.
lead_para: If some financial institutions had used blockchains before the last recession, we may not have had one. After all, banks sometimes didn’t know which company’s books held bad mortgages, and a blockchain is essentially a single time-stamped ledger transparent to all its users.
headline: Industries, Looking for Efficiency, Turn to Blockchains

abstract: Under development for six years, IBM Debater reflects a push toward machines that talk like humans. But it may have to work on getting to the point.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — A match between an Israeli college debate champion and a loquacious IBM computer program demonstrated on Monday new gains in the quest for computers that can hold conversations with humans. It also led to an unlikely question for the tech industry’s deep thinkers: Can a machine talk too much?
headline: IBM Unveils System That ‘Debates’ With Humans

abstract: For five and half years IBM has reported a steady erosion of revenue, a losing streak that analysts predict will end on Thursday.
lead_para: For five and a half years, nearly the entire tenure of its chief executive, Virginia M. Rometty, IBM has reported a steady erosion of revenue.
headline: IBM May Finally Stop Shrinking. But Is It a Turnaround?

abstract: The gain was modest — revenue rose by 4 percent — but the company’s fourth-quarter report is a sign that IBM’s finances are stabilizing.
lead_para: IBM reported revenue growth for the first time in five and a half years on Thursday, ending a streak of 22 consecutive quarters of shrinking sales.
headline: IBM Ends 22-Quarter Streak of Falling Revenue

abstract: Four big banks announce fourth-quarter results, an economic giant may be shifting gears and a film festival proceeds without one of its most active shoppers.
lead_para: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead:
headline: More Bank Earnings, China’s Growth and Sundance Without Weinstein

abstract: Technology is advancing by leaps and bounds.
lead_para: Donald Trump poses a huge dilemma for commentators: to ignore his daily outrages is to normalize his behavior, but to constantly write about them is to stop learning. Like others, I struggle to get this balance right, which is why I pause today to point out some incredible technological changes happening while Trump has kept us focused on him — changes that will pose as big an adaptation challenge to American workers as transitioning from farms to factories once did.
headline: While You Were Sleeping

abstract: Tim Cook and Ginni Rometty have recently criticized Facebook. But don’t expect a long lineup of other tech industry leaders to speak out anytime soon.
lead_para: The recent tribulations of Facebook, which has lurched from crisis to crisis over the last year, most recently over the handling of users’ personal data, has pushed a few of the industry’s most prominent names to speak out against the company.
headline: As Facebook Struggles, Rivals’ Leaders Stay (Mostly) Mum

abstract: A leader in IBM’s development of a speech-recognition system, she relied on her laptop to communicate after Lou Gehrig’s disease left her paralyzed.
lead_para: Catherine Wolf, an experimental psychologist whose research focused on enhancing interactions between humans and computers — and who, after illness left her paralyzed, relied on her laptop to communicate, using a system that let her wiggle an eyebrow to pick out letters — died on Feb. 7 at her home in Katonah, N.Y. She was 70.
headline: Catherine Wolf, 70, Dies; Studied How People and Computers Interact

abstract: The giant retailer will begin requiring lettuce and spinach suppliers to contribute to a blockchain database that can rapidly pinpoint contamination.
lead_para: When dozens of people across the country got sick from eating contaminated romaine lettuce this spring, Walmart did what many grocers would do: It cleared every shred off its shelves, just to be safe.
headline: From Farm to Blockchain: Walmart Tracks Its Lettuce

abstract: The Ad Council — along with G.E., Google, IBM, Microsoft and Verizon — is trying to encourage girls ages 11 to 15 to get involved in science, technology, engineering and math.
lead_para: Bonnie Ross, head of Microsoft’s Halo game studio, says, “You have the power to bring new worlds to life.” Maya Gupta, a Google research scientist, advises, “Don’t just solve the problem, write the code.” And Lisa Seacat DeLuca, a distinguished engineer at IBM, suggests, “If you can imagine it, it’s possible.”
headline: Role Models Tell Girls That STEM’s for Them in New Campaign

abstract: Timothy D. Cook of Apple, Ginni Rometty of IBM and dozens of other C.E.O.s said new guidelines and practices were hindering skilled foreign workers and harmful to economic growth.
lead_para: Dozens of American business leaders are challenging the Trump administration over changes to immigration policy that they say threaten the livelihoods of thousands of their skilled foreign workers, and the nation’s economic growth and competitiveness as well.
headline: Top C.E.O.s Denounce Trump Immigration Policy as Threat to U.S. Economy

abstract: Scientists at a company lab said they had taken a big step toward creating a machine that would make today’s supercomputers look like toys.
lead_para: SANTA BARBARA, Calif. — Google said on Wednesday that it had achieved a long-sought breakthrough called “quantum supremacy,” which could allow new kinds of computers to do calculations at speeds that are inconceivable with today’s technology.
headline: Google Claims a Quantum Breakthrough That Could Change Computing

abstract: The defense secretary’s son worked for one of the contract’s original bidders.
lead_para: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper recused himself from reviewing a controversial $10 billion cloud-computing contract because his son works for one of the contract’s original bidders, the Defense Department said on Tuesday.
headline: Esper Removes Himself From Reviewing Cloud-Computing Contract

abstract: With transmons and entanglement, scientists strive to put subatomic weirdness to work on the human scale.
lead_para: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y. — A bolt from the maybe-future struck the technology community in late September. A paper by Google computer scientists appeared on a NASA website, claiming that an innovative new machine called a quantum computer had demonstrated “quantum supremacy.”
headline: Quantum Computing Is Coming, Bit by Qubit

abstract: Quantum computing is a national security priority, and a big focus of competition in the technology industry.
lead_para: This was not just any math problem.
headline: Quantum Computing Explained (in Mere Minutes!)

abstract: The company can run esoteric calculations on exotic new hardware faster than is possible on a supercomputer. It’s an achievement of little practical use, but still important.
lead_para: Each week, we review the week’s news, offering analysis about the most important developments in the tech industry.
headline: The Week in Tech: Google’s Quantum Leap

abstract: Andrew Ross Sorkin hosts a series of discussions with some of the biggest newsmakers at the intersection of business and policy at this year’s event.
lead_para: Get the DealBook newsletter to make sense of major business and policy headlines — and the power-brokers who shape them.__________
headline: Gates, Clinton, Hastings, Kardashian, Chesky, Muilenburg: DealBook Conference 2019

abstract: Pay for gas. Deposit a check. Book a flight. Many of us often take for granted the variety of important tasks we’re able to accomplish on our smartphones and mobile devices — and how seamless that makes our lives.
headline: When Open Meets Secure

abstract: To design a cloud secure enough for BNP Paribas, IBM first had to resolve 200 compliance requirements.
headline: A Global Bank Hosted in the Public Cloud — Can That Be Safe?

abstract: The chief executives for Johnson & Johnson and IBM said businesses had a responsibility to both employees and customers.
lead_para: Communicating with employees is a bit like building a bank account, according to Alex Gorsky, the chief executive of Johnson & Johnson: making contributions over time, developing a reservoir of trust, because “someday you’re likely going to need to make a withdrawal.”
headline: Looking Beyond Profits

abstract: Professional hackers work to keep people safe by finding security vulnerabilities before criminals do.
lead_para: When asked what his father did for a living, my son explained to his kindergarten teacher that “he steals things, but it’s O.K. because he gets paid to do it.”
headline: Most Hackers Aren’t Criminals

abstract: ExxonMobil and IBM reach for the cloud to bring convenience and extra security to the pump.
headline: What Can Gas Stations Teach Us About Digital Transformation?

abstract: Etihad Airways is giving its guests more choices by migrating to IBM’s public cloud.
headline: Do You Wish Air Travel Was More Personalized?

abstract: Severe weather conditions, especially hurricanes, bring a deluge of traffic to the site, which millions of Americans rely on for real-time, around-the-clock updates.
headline: How weather.com Withstands Digital Storms

abstract: It’s not the first self-driving bike. But equipped with an A.I. chip, it may be the nearest to thinking for itself.
lead_para: As corporate giants like Ford, G.M. and Waymo struggle to get their self-driving cars on the road, a team of researchers in China is rethinking autonomous transportation using a souped-up bicycle.
headline: And Now, a Bicycle Built for None

abstract: With the acquisition of a leading business software company, IBM is presenting itself as an open, impartial player in the cloud computing industry.
lead_para: IBM has tried multiple ways to stay relevant in the technology world. But it has often been outgunned by rivals like Amazon and Microsoft.
headline: IBM Bets $34 Billion That Red Hat Can Help It Catch Amazon and Microsoft

abstract: The hospital technology, typically used to identify human ailments, captured perhaps the world’s smallest magnetic resonance image.
lead_para: As our devices get smaller and more sophisticated, so do the materials we use to make them. That means we have to get up close to engineer new materials. Really close.
headline: Scientists Took an M.R.I. Scan of an Atom

abstract: With S/4HANA, SAP has introduced the latest version of its world-class software suite. IBM can ensure that your ERP transformation is implemented expertly and securely to prepare your business for the future.
headline: For Digital Evolution, the Right Partner Is Key

abstract: Artificial Intelligence is a fast-growing technology, one that could drive dramatic advances in medicine, education, transportation, banking – and everything in between.
headline: The Force for Change in A.I.: More Women

abstract: Why you should focus on linking people and technology.
headline: The Key to Business Modernization

abstract: One of the world’s largest food and beverage companies needed a process to measure sales and to rapidly deploy new solutions across its portfolio of 200 brands.
headline: Why Digital Transformation Starts With Workflows That Unite People and Technology

abstract: In a lawsuit on Thursday, the city attorney said tracking was used not just for local forecasts but also for commercial purposes like targeted marketing.
lead_para: The Weather Channel app deceptively collected, shared and profited from the location information of millions of American consumers, the city attorney of Los Angeles said in a lawsuit filed on Thursday.
headline: Los Angeles Accuses Weather Channel App of Covertly Mining User Data

abstract: In an attempt to better compete with other Grand Slam tournaments, the French Open is renovating and reaching out to young fans, and has increased the prizes.
lead_para: A new era begins for the French Open this month as Roland Garros begins to unveil its renovations and new courts, including the new 5,000-seat arena, named after the French tennis star Simonne Mathieu, which has a semisunken court surrounded by 19th-century greenhouses. A retractable roof is planned for next year.
headline: The French Open Spruces Up, and Shows Players the Money

abstract: Using a quantum computer, physicists successfully reversed time for an artificial atom. You can even try it at home.
lead_para: In “The Curious Case of Benjamin Button,” a story by F. Scott Fitzgerald and then a movie starring Brad Pitt, a man ages backward: He is born an old man, regresses over the years and dies an infant.
headline: For a Split Second, a Quantum Computer Made History Go Backward

abstract: As the Treasury Department prepared to enact the 2017 Republican tax overhaul, corporate lobbyists swarmed — and won big.
lead_para: The overhaul of the federal tax law in 2017 was the signature legislative achievement of Donald J. Trump’s presidency.
headline: How Big Companies Won New Tax Breaks From the Trump Administration

abstract: Every purchase evokes his design of the rectangular Universal Product Code. But although it became ubiquitous, he received no royalties.
lead_para: George J. Laurer, whose design of the vertically striped bar code sped supermarket checkout lines, parcel deliveries and assembly lines and even transformed human beings, including airline passengers and hospital patients, into traceable inventory items, died on Dec. 5 at his home in Wendell, N.C., near Raleigh. He was 94.
headline: George Laurer, Who Developed the Bar Code, Is Dead at 94

abstract: Software looks to be at the heart of the recent Ethiopian Airlines crash. Safety approval of such systems will only get harder as technology advances.
lead_para: Hi. I’m Jamie Condliffe. Greetings from London. Here’s a look at the week’s tech news:
headline: The Week in Tech: Our Future Robots Will Need Super-Smart Safety Checks

abstract: Life is a lot easier when you can plug in to any socket.
lead_para: Our modern existence depends on things we can take for granted. Cars run on gas from any gas station, the plugs for electrical devices fit into any socket, and smartphones connect to anything equipped with Bluetooth. All of these conveniences depend on technical standards, the silent and often forgotten foundations of technological societies.
headline: The Joy of Standards

abstract: What kinds of companies will be the next so-called unicorns? A hint: Many of them won’t have much in common with Uber or Airbnb.
lead_para: Hi. I’m Steve Lohr. I write about the technology industry, from the old titans like IBM to start-ups working on the future of artificial intelligence.
headline: The Week in Tech: A Break From Consumer Tech

abstract: Fledgling gal-bots are the latest hires in the virtual assistant landscape.
headline: Driving A.I. Acceptance: Learning From Mia and Marge

abstract: Australia’s Woodside Energy had decades of knowledge instilled in its retiring workforce of oil pipeline engineers and wanted to scale that wealth to a much more expansive workforce.
headline: A.I.: Your Next Career Move

abstract: IBM has recently launched its inaugural IBM Women Leaders in A.I. in recognition of women advancing their company’s journey to artificial intelligence across diverse industries around the globe.
headline: Unhidden Figures: Are Women A.I.’s Natural Born Leaders?

abstract: The split-up strategy reflects how decisively computing has shifted to the cloud.
lead_para: IBM, throughout its 109-year history, hasn’t often led technology trends. But it has adapted and eventually prospered time and again.
headline: IBM, Seeing Its Future in the Cloud, Breaks Off I.T. Unit

abstract: Lynn Conway was one of the company’s most promising young computer engineers but after confiding to supervisors that she was transgender, they fired her.
lead_para: In August 1968, Lynn Conway, a promising computer engineer at IBM in Sunnyvale, Calif., was called into the office of Gene Myron Amdahl, then the company’s director of advanced computing systems.
headline: 52 Years Later, IBM Apologizes for Firing Transgender Woman

abstract: According to a new survey about Americans’ economic priorities, most don’t want to return to business as usual after the pandemic.
lead_para: Want this in your inbox each morning? Sign up here.
headline: Respond, Reopen, Reset

abstract: Corporate America has pledged millions to social justice efforts since the killing of George Floyd. But some businesses have gone further, committing to concrete changes in their practices.
lead_para: Friday will be a paid company holiday for employees at Nike. The same goes for workers at Twitter, Target, General Motors, the National Football League and a variety of other businesses. JPMorgan Chase, Capital One and other banks will close branches early.
headline: Here’s What Companies Are Promising to Do to Fight Racism

abstract: The company said it hoped the moratorium “might give Congress enough time to put in place appropriate rules” for the technology.
lead_para: SEATTLE — Amazon said on Wednesday that it was putting a one-year pause on letting the police use its facial recognition tool, in a major sign of the growing concerns that the technology may lead to unfair treatment of African-Americans.
headline: Amazon Pauses Police Use of Its Facial Recognition Software

abstract: Arvind Krishna, who has led the company’s cloud computing business, was named the new chief executive.
lead_para: Ginni Rometty, the longtime face of IBM and one of the country’s most prominent female business leaders, is stepping down as chief executive, the company said on Thursday.
headline: Ginni Rometty to Step Down as C.E.O. of IBM

abstract: Some European companies seem to be targeting workers who are the easiest to fire or have the least bargaining power, even as the firms seek government help.
lead_para: FRANKFURT — As the German airline Lufthansa struggles to stay in business, it’s no surprise that its employees are suffering, too. But as is the case at other struggling companies, some workers are suffering more than others.
headline: Europe’s Strong Labor Laws Aren’t a Guarantee for Lower-Wage Workers

abstract: IBM has found that companies and governments have been targeted by unknown attackers, prompting a warning from the Homeland Security Department.
lead_para: A series of cyberattacks is underway aimed at the companies and government organizations that will be distributing coronavirus vaccines around the world, IBM’s cybersecurity division has found, though it is unclear whether the goal is to steal the technology for keeping the vaccines refrigerated in transit or to sabotage the movements.
headline: Cyberattacks Discovered on Vaccine Distribution Operations

abstract: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
lead_para: SAN FRANCISCO — With an iPhone, you can dictate a text message. Put Amazon’s Alexa on your coffee table, and you can request a song from across the room.
headline: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say

abstract: One of the few women in the computer industry in its early days, she paved the way for the efficient, lightning-fast apps of today.
lead_para: Frances Allen, a computer scientist and researcher who helped create the fundamental ideas that allow practically anyone to build fast, efficient and useful software for computers, smartphones and websites, died on Tuesday, her 88th birthday, in Schenectady, N.Y.
headline: Frances Allen, Who Helped Hardware Understand Software, Dies at 88

abstract: IBM’s artificial intelligence was supposed to transform industries and generate riches for the company. Neither has panned out. Now, IBM has settled on a humbler vision for Watson.
lead_para: A decade ago, IBM’s public confidence was unmistakable. Its Watson supercomputer had just trounced Ken Jennings, the best human “Jeopardy!” player ever, showcasing the power of artificial intelligence. This was only the beginning of a technological revolution about to sweep through society, the company pledged.
headline: What Ever Happened to IBM’s Watson?

abstract: When Big Blue left upstate New York, economic pain ensued. But the large complexes left behind are ideally suited for large-scale production and shipping, local officials say.
lead_para: ENDICOTT, N.Y. — The sidewalks along Washington Avenue in Endicott, N.Y., are empty enough that bicycles cruise their length with smooth sailing. But 40 years ago, when an IBM plant hummed with thousands of employees, the cyclists might have picked a different route.
headline: A Renewal for IBM Campuses Once Home to Punch Cards and Circuit Boards

abstract: More than one million Excelsior passes have been downloaded since they were introduced, but officials are hoping they will be adopted more widely.
lead_para: On the Upper East Side in Manhattan, a well-heeled crowd flashed it to get into a socially distanced dance performance at the Park Avenue Armory. In Chelsea, people showed it to attend a John Mulaney stand-up set at City Winery. And in Troy, N.Y., patrons are using it to enter an intimate, speakeasy-style bar that only admits vaccinated guests.
headline: Will the Excelsior Pass, New York’s Vaccine Passport, Catch On?

abstract: As companies put their donations to candidates on hold, they should reassess political giving entirely, making the halt permanent.
lead_para: As companies from Coca-Cola to Amazon to Citigroup appear to be tripping over one another to declare that they are “pausing” or “reassessing” donations to Republicans who sought to overturn the election — and, in some cases, suspending giving to both parties — they might want to look at a company that didn’t say anything.
headline: ‘An Epiphany Moment’ for Corporate Political Donors May Have Arrived

abstract: IBM doesn’t donate to politicians. Perhaps others shouldn’t, either.
lead_para: [Read more on Trump and Pence.]
headline: Getting Corporate Cash Out of Politics

abstract: President-elect Joe Biden’s $1.9 trillion economic plan will run up big debts.
lead_para: President-elect Joe Biden unveiled his $1.9 trillion economic rescue plan yesterday, an ambitious package of bigger direct payments to Americans, extra funding for coronavirus vaccine distribution and more. The move is a bolder response than the Obama administration’s to the 2008 financial crisis — even if it runs up debt to dizzying levels.
headline: That’s a Lot of Money

abstract: Jake Siewert led the firm’s post-financial crisis reputation makeover.
lead_para: For nearly a decade, Jake Siewert led Goldman Sachs’s post-crisis efforts to shed its image as one of Wall Street’s most mysterious, and maligned, money machines. We’re the first to report that he plans to announce his departure later today.
headline: Goldman Sachs’s Top Image Maker Is Leaving

abstract: Business leaders are trained to “shoot, move and communicate.” But the pandemic has called on them to rewrite the leadership playbook.
lead_para: In normal times, there are few words that C.E.O.s like more than “certainty.” Certainty allows executives to issue sales forecasts with oracle-like conviction. Certainty instills leaders with the confidence they need to invest $500 million in a new factory, or spend $20 billion buying a competitor. Certainty gives them the verve they need to preside over virtual town hall meetings with their employees and discuss race relations, furloughs, remote work and more.
headline: ‘We Threw Out Any Plans We Had’: C.E.O.s Are Forced to Embrace Uncertainty

abstract: IBM researchers trained artificial intelligence to pick up hints of changes in language ahead of the onset of neurological diseases.
lead_para: Is it possible to predict who will develop Alzheimer’s disease simply by looking at writing patterns years before there are symptoms?
headline: Alzheimer’s Prediction May Be Found in Writing Tests

abstract: There’s a hidden hurdle.
lead_para: Business leaders, investors and regulators are all pushing to make corporate America’s boardrooms more diverse. But as a Salesforce executive learned, there are sometimes hidden hurdles to making that happen, Andrew writes in his latest column.
headline: What’s Delaying Boardroom Diversity

abstract: President Biden traveled to Poughkeepsie, N.Y., to connect a $20 billion investment by IBM to the bipartisan bill meant to spur production of critical microchips.
lead_para: President Biden visited the Hudson Valley of New York on Thursday to tour an IBM facility after the company announced it would invest $20 billion across the region to increase its production of semiconductors and develop advanced technologies, including artificial intelligence and quantum computing.
headline: Biden Visits IBM to Promote Investments in U.S. Semiconductor Production

abstract: During his visit to IBM’s Hudson Valley facility in New York, President Biden highlighted the CHIPS and Science Act that provides subsidies to companies that sign up to jump-start domestic production of semiconductor chips.
lead_para: During his visit to IBM’s Hudson Valley facility in New York, President Biden highlighted the CHIPS and Science Act that provides subsidies to companies that sign up to jump-start domestic production of semiconductor chips.
headline: Biden Promotes IBM’s $20 Billion Manufacturing Deal in New York

abstract: He was a lead designer of the computers that cemented IBM’s dominance for decades. He later wrote a book on software engineering that became a quirky classic.
lead_para: Frederick P. Brooks Jr., whose innovative work in computer design and software engineering helped shape the field of computer science, died on Thursday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 91.
headline: Frederick P. Brooks Jr., Computer Design Innovator, Dies at 91

abstract: The sale is part of IBM’s effort to tighten the focus of its business and shed operations.
lead_para: IBM is selling its Watson Health data and analytics business, the final step in the company’s retreat from what it once called a “moonshot” venture to improve health care, helping save lives and trim medical costs.
headline: IBM is selling off Watson Health to a private equity firm.

abstract: New research finds companies are starting to rely less on the college filter in hiring. But it remains an obstacle to opportunity for many.
lead_para: As a middle school student in New York, Shekinah Griffith saw a television news report of President Barack Obama visiting an innovative school in Brooklyn. Its program included high school, an associate degree in a technical subject, an internship and the promise of a good job.
headline: A 4-Year Degree Isn’t Quite the Job Requirement It Used to Be

abstract: Arvind Krishna is trying to stay in touch with the company’s roots as he confronts today’s challenges.
lead_para: In a tech industry dominated by Apple, Alphabet, Meta and Microsoft, it can be easy to forget that much of the humdrum work that makes screens flicker, servers hum and businesses run is performed by companies that rarely make the headlines, companies that have been gradually shaping the computer business for decades, companies like IBM.
headline: An Optimist at the Helm of IBM

abstract: Customer service chatbots may finally become more intelligent, more conversational and more helpful.
lead_para: This article is part of a new series on artificial intelligence’s potential to solve everyday problems.
headline: Ending the Chatbot’s ‘Spiral of Misery’

abstract: Documents released in an age-discrimination case appear to show high-level discussion about paring the ranks of older employees.
lead_para: In recent years, former IBM employees have accused the company of age discrimination in a variety of legal filings and press accounts, arguing that IBM sought to replace thousands of older workers with younger ones to keep pace with corporate rivals.
headline: Making ‘Dinobabies’ Extinct: IBM’s Push for a Younger Work Force

abstract: Artificial intelligence systems can process vast amounts of data in seconds, but they can’t make sense of the world or explain their decisions. David Ferrucci wants to change that.
lead_para: David Ferrucci, who led the team that built IBM’s famed Watson computer, was elated when it beat the best-ever human “Jeopardy!” players in 2011, in a televised triumph for artificial intelligence.
headline: One Man’s Dream of Fusing A.I. With Common Sense

abstract: “I knew at some point in time the patent office would recognize” computer software, he said. It happened in 1968, helping to ignite the software market.
lead_para: Martin Goetz, who joined the computer industry in its infancy in the mid-1950s as a programmer working on Univac mainframes and who later received the first U.S. patent for software, died on Oct. 10 at his home in Brighton, Mass. He was 93.
headline: Martin Goetz, Who Received the First Software Patent, Dies at 93

abstract: In “The Greatest Capitalist Who Ever Lived,” Ralph Watson McElvenny and Marc Wortman show how Oedipal battles fueled the company’s technological triumphs in the 1960s and beyond.
lead_para: Thomas J. Watson Jr. seemed, from a young age, to be destined for failure. Born in 1914, he was an angry and often depressed young boy. Neighbors called him “Terrible Tommy.” He barely gained his high school diploma after attending three different schools. His father, Watson Sr., the head of IBM, was a domineering man who subjected his son to a classic combination of emotional distance and cruelty. Watson Jr. responded by becoming a rebel and wastrel.
headline: The Father-Son Struggle That Helped Ensure IBM’s Success

abstract: As the downsides of 401(k)-style plans become apparent, workers and some companies, including IBM, are showing new interest in defined benefit plans.
lead_para: In an economy characterized by a volatile stock market and elevated inflation, a sure thing looks better than ever. For some Americans in the labor force right now, that looks like a pension.
headline: The Pension: That Rare Retirement Benefit Gets a Fresh Look

abstract: IBM, a major advertiser on X, has pulled its spending from the social media platform, whose employees are grappling with what to tell its other advertisers, according to internal messages.
lead_para: Less than 24 hours after Elon Musk endorsed an antisemitic post on X as “the actual truth” of what Jewish people were doing, IBM paused its advertising on the social media platform as X’s chief executive, Linda Yaccarino, and others at the company scrambled on Thursday to contain the fallout.
headline: X Races to Contain Damage After Elon Musk Endorses Antisemitic Post

abstract: Disney, Apple, Paramount and Lionsgate halted marketing on X, formerly Twitter, as Elon Musk faced a furor over antisemitic abuse on his social media platform.
lead_para: The blowback over Elon Musk’s endorsement of an antisemitic conspiracy theory on X gathered steam on Friday, as several major advertisers on his social media platform cut off their spending after his comments.
headline: Advertisers Flee X as Outcry Over Musk’s Endorsement of Antisemitic Post Grows

abstract: Companies, celebrities and influencers have taken TikTok and X  — and Elon Musk himself — to task for the rise of hate speech on their platforms since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel.
lead_para: The rise in antisemitism since the outbreak of war in the Middle East has ignited a clash between Wall Street donors and universities, and divided some workplaces.
